questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with multiple sexual partners presents with painful genital sores that started two days ago, accompanied by flu-like symptoms, fever, and headache. Examination shows shallow ulcers (as shown in the image) and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. A swab of the ulcer has been sent for testing. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with sudden confusion, fever, and seizures over the past 24 hours. Her partner reports memory loss and difficulty recognising faces. Examination reveals a fever of 102°F, disorientation, and mild aphasia. PCR is positive for HSV. Which feature is not associated with the causative organism?

A 6-month-old infant presents with a 1-week history of fever, irritability, decreased appetite, and lethargy. Examination reveals high temperature, moderate hepatomegaly, and purpura/petechiae on the trunk and extremities. CBC shows thrombocytopenia and leukopenia. ELISA detects antibodies for antigen PP65. What is the cause of the condition?
questions.explanation:
CMV infection

Modes of transmission
  • Oral route, respiratory & body secretions (most common)
  • Vertical transmission
  • Sexual transmission
  • Organ transplantation
  • Blood transfusion

Host cells
  • Salivary gland
  • Kidney

Clinical features

Congenital infection
  • Most common intrauterine infection with congenital defects.
  • Common presentation:
    • Petechiae
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Jaundice
  • Less common presentation:
    • Microcephaly
    • Cerebral calcifications
    • Intrauterine growth retardation
    • Prematurity
  • Other defects: Sensorineural hearing loss.

Perinatal infection
  • Commonly asymptomatic.
  • Occasionally, premature infants present with interstitial pneumonitis.

Immunocompromised
  • Seen in AIDS, HIV, organ transplant patients and cancer patients undergoing chemo
  • Presentations in AIDS and HIV
    • CMV chorioretinitis
    • Progressive dementia,
    • Cranial nerve defects,
  • Presentations in Organ transplant
    • Bilateral interstitial pneumonia
    • Febrile leukopenia
    • Obliterative bronchiolitis
    • Graft atherosclerosis
    • Rejection of renal allografts.

Immunocompetent
  • Usually, it occurs following a blood transfusion.
  • It presents similar to infectious mononucleosis, but heterophile antibody tests would be negative.

Investigations

Peripheral smear

Owl’s eye appearance of inclusion bodies

Virus isolation

It is done by

  • Human fibroblast cell line culture
  • Shell vial culture

Antigen detected

PP65

Antibody detection

It is done by ELISA, and the antibodies detected are

  • CMV IgM antibodies
  • CMV IgG antibodies
  • Against PP150 and PP65,
  • Against the PP52

PCR
  • Used in detecting CMV DNA
  • Quantitative nucleic acid testing (QNAT) by PCR is the most sensitive and specific testing.

Treatment
  • Ganciclovir (Drug of choice)
  • Foscarnet (in Ganciclovir resistance)
  • CMV immunoglobulins and Ganciclovir are given to bone marrow transplant patients.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male wrestler presents with a painful rash on his forehead and neck, initially small red bumps that developed into fluid-filled blisters (shown in the image). He reports fever and malaise for the past few days. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Match the following herpes virus with its corresponding microscopic findings. 1. Herpes Simplex Virus A. 2. Epstein Barr Virus B. 3. Cytomegalovirus C. 4. Human herpes virus type 8 D.
questions.explanation:
Herpes simplex virus

  • Tzanck smear: Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained 'ground-glass' chromatin (Tzanck cells).
  • Formation of Lipschutz bodies (Cowdry type A).

EBV (Epstein Barr virus)

  • Downey cells: Atypical lymphocytes (large, vacuolated) are observed.
  • Ballerina skirt appearance.

CMV (Cytomegalovirus)

  • The presence of inclusion bodies gives the characteristic “Owl-eye appearance”.

HHV 8 (human herpes virus type 8)

  • Castleman disease: Onion skinning of lymphocytes and blood vessels, giving the appearance of “Lollipop follicles”.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 20 weeks gestation reports a mild rash, fever, and flu-like symptoms after exposure to a child with a rash. Ultrasound shows cicatricial lesions, limb hypoplasia, microcephaly, and intrauterine growth restriction. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old male with a history of diabetes presents with a painful rash on the right side of his torso. He reports that the pain began as a burning sensation a few days ago, and he has since developed red, blistering, and tender lesions, as shown below. What is the most common complication of this condition?

A 25-year-old female presents with severe fatigue, a sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes for the past week, noting a similar illness in her partner. Examination shows low-grade fever, mild hepatosplenomegaly, and cervical lymphadenopathy. A complete blood count indicates absolute lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 21-year-old male presents with extreme fatigue, a severe sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes for two weeks, with similar recent symptoms in his partner. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly and cervical lymphadenopathy, and lab results showed a high percentage of atypical lymphocytes. All the following malignancies are associated with it except?
questions.explanation:
Types of malignancy

Examples

Carcinoma

  • Gastric carcinoma (most common) (Option C)
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (Option D)

Lymphoma

  • Hodgkin’s lymphoma (most common lymphocyte depletion and mixed cellularity)
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
    • Burkitt’s lymphoma (Option B)
    • DLBCL (diffuse large B cell lymphoma)
    • Post-transplant lymphoma
    • T or NK cell lymphoma

Sarcoma

  • Leiomyosarcoma

questions.text: A 22-year-old male college student comes in with a 1-week history of fever, significant fatigue, sore throat, and swollen cervical lymph nodes. Examination shows elevated temperature, bilateral tender lymphadenopathy, and tonsillar enlargement with exudate. His CBC reveals leukocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. How does the heterophile agglutination test aid in diagnosing his condition?
questions.correct_answer: D. Antibodies react with sheep RBC
questions.explanation:
Investigations for EBV

Peripheral smear
  • Initially, leukopenia is noted, often followed by leukocytosis as the condition progresses.
  • The presence of atypical mononuclear cells (derived from cytotoxic T cells) exhibits basophilic vacuolated cytoplasm and kidney-shaped nuclei (Downey cells).
  • Ballerina skirt appearance: Characteristic morphology where atypical lymphocytes have cytoplasm that extends and flares, resembling a ballerina’s skirt.

Serology

Heterophile antibody test (Non-specific antibody test)
  • Paul-Bunnell test: Heterophile antibodies react with Sheep RBC.
  • Monospot test: Heterophile antibodies react with Horse RBC.

Specific antibody test (ELISA or Immunofluorescence)
  • lgM antibody against Viral Capsid antigen (earliest antigen) (Option C).
  • Antibody against the EB nuclear antigen (EBNA) (Option B).
  • Antibodies against early antigens (Option A).

Culture

For Virus isolation

Not commonly used.

Other tests
  • PCR
  • Nucleic acid hybridisation test (Most sensitive & specific)

Conditions caused

HHV 6
  • In children: Sixth disease/ Roseola/ Exanthem Subitum (sudden high fever followed by a distinctive rash)
  • In adults: Infectious mononucleosis-like symptoms and focal encephalitis (Option B)
  • In Immunodeficient - Pneumonia and Disseminated disease.

HHV 7

Causes Sixth disease/ Roseola/ Exanthem Subitum in children

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with HIV presents with fever, weight loss, and reddish-purple raised skin lesions. A biopsy shows spindle-shaped cells with mixed inflammatory infiltrate, and serological testing reveals antibodies to Human Herpesvirus 8. Which of the following statements regarding HHV 8 is false?

options.label: A
options.text: HHV 8 can cause primary effusion lymphoma

options.label: D
options.text: HHV 8 does not spread through oral secretions

questions.correct_answer: D. HHV 8 does not spread through oral secretions
questions.explanation:
HHV 8

Investigations
  • PCR
  • Serological tests: Indirect immunofluorescence, Western blot and ELISA.

Clinical conditions
  • Kaposi sarcoma: (Option B)
    • Commonly affected sites are lower limbs, followed by lymph nodes.
    • It commonly affects the immunocompromised people.
  • Primary effusion lymphoma (Option A)
  • Castleman's disease: (Option C)
    • It is a rare lymphoproliferative disorder characterised by the abnormal growth of lymphoid tissue.
    • Lollipop follicles are a distinctive histological feature seen in lymphoid tissue in this condition.
